comments.commentBody:
Most of the comments here are about cultural norms, so I’m not sure how seeing one or even several exceptions to an observation invalidates it.

Most of us wold agree (I think!) that the large majority of Americans fluently speak one language: English. That's the cultural here.

There are a good number of Americans who can fluently speak two languages or more. That doesn’t make observation, “The norm for Americans is to speak one language: English,” false.

Nor does seeing a French child throw a tantrum prove that French children generally behave the same way as American children.

American culture has certain strengths that other places don’t have and could benefit from adopting. But I’ve spent time in Paris, and I have to say, from my limited exposure, the observations of author and many of the commenters here bear out: on average, French children tend to eat a much wider variety of foods – and have vastly better table manners – than their American counterparts.

If fast food increases its foothold there, I suspect that will change over time.

I loved your article, yet I wish to interject that my take on the comments of Mz. Rosen is different from yours. It seemed to me that she stated that Ann Romney, as a life-long homemaker, did not have the training or experience to be considered an expert in economics/labor/politics. I did not see a condemnation of motherhood in her statements.

As I see it, her statement was used to create a flap where none really existed. Ann Romney seems to be a very nice woman, and a fine mother, but I would not hire her to provide expertise on the U.S. economy, although she would probably have a great deal of wisdom on child-rearing to impart of Mz Rosen.

Frank Bruni, I admire your forthright, beautifully expressed and difficult task of writing about your mother and who she was and what she meant to you, and to all of your family; many thanks.

I was born in the late thirties, the eldest of six, to my mother four days before her twenty first birthday. She was busily engaged with her family all of her life and like your mother excelled at everything she did. She did not "work" until her late forties when she began to model and perform in TV commercials, from whence she went on to start her own successful business.

The issue in question, and your position on the matter will likely generate some sparks and heat among the NYT audience who in their best tradition are wont to see some issues not by traditional liberal standards, but in absolutist terms, of their being correct in every respect and every one else being incorrect, ill informed or worse, even prejudiced against mothers.

As I said above I admire your essay; and I am proud that both of us, who are frankly of contrasting political opinions, of different generations, and of great experience about our beloved mothers, conclude that there is great value in all of what our mothers accomplished, and in what all mothers do.
I am glad you said it !  I don't how French children are less creative, empathetic and show less initiative than American kids!

"I think they could learn from us about creativity, empathy and individual initiative — traits that are not fostered by traditional French parenting"

A good editor would remove a silly sentence like this, for the good of the essay as a whole. Sheesh.
Great interview. Smart New Jersey Girl!
thank you Lens . NYT  your expertise

I agree with you that poverty/affluence are related to healthy eating. But it cannot explain the huge jump in obesity; obesity hasn't always been the problem that it is today, and poverty has always been with us. The percentage of people in poverty is not much higher today than it was 20-30 years ago, so the change in poverty cannot explain the jump in obesity. So, what can be responsible for the increase in obesity? Parenting, definitely. The increase in fast-food restaurants in poor neighborhoods, yep.  The increase in highly processed foods, too. What else?

Both my kids went to a very good daycare and I absolutely did not see kids as being "desperately waiting for their parents to pick them up".
All daycares are not equal and most are staffed by very caring staff. I don't understand this phobia of daycares for normal, healthy kids.

Check out "daycaresdontcare.org". I have never seen a wonderful daycare. The hours are too long, the babies too young. My daughter goes to friends' houses for 2 hours. Three at tops. She has never gone to a friends' house for 8 hours, the time a tot typically spends at a daycare.

MY child's family daycare was wonderful, but it was mornings only -- 8 to 1. There were no exhausted, stressed little daycare veterans there. I was lucky to be able to swing this and I know it is not how it works for many people.

I did writing and project management at home. To get my work done I hired college students for the afternoon shift. Almost two decades later we are still friendly with both his daycare provider and one of his student babysitters.

Part-time daycare plus sitters worked for me.

I have worked at a child care center -- a good, parent-run one with NAEYC accreditation. For easy going children I did not see issues with their being there all day. For more sensitive or needy children, I felt the long day wasn't in their best interest. But full day care allows for parents to pay the rent and bills and keep the boat afloat. We have made that our national priority by not subsidizing child care for the middle class, so we must live with that set of values.

Ms. Badinter finds that women are disadvantaged to men— because women decide to have children! Then, women should not have children? Then who would replace us— as each generation us Americans passes on and gets replaced by another? Afterall, we are fortunate to have a person like Ms. Badinter among us and thankful that her dear mother who decided to bring Ms. Badinter to this world! If all American women were to accept Ms. Badinter’s prescription and not have any children anymore, just so that they could be entirely equal to men—there’ll be no one left in America, women or men! I now get your point Ms. Badinter, then the problem of inequality will not rise at all! But,  I have to point out there’s something more sinister lurks under the Ms. Badinter book —and that’s the anti-children tone of her writing. American children are neglected and ignored by both men and women today— they are raised socially without the privacy or comfort of their homes, in collective group situations— staffed by distracted and under qualified, poorly paid child care workers, where children spend nearly ten hours each day, even infanats only few weeks old— desperately waiting for their parents to pick them up, each day—all year! Given the pain and suffering of America children, who are voiceless and ignored—even by the nations most fervent human rights activits—we hardly need Ms. Badinter’s condemnation of our children— to suggest they even do not have a right to exist!

When I was pregnant with my first, we were stone-cold broke, so eating a healthy diet was not an option, and neither was going in for regular checkups. I didn't smoke, stayed away from alcohol after the pregnancy was confirmed, and I drank coffee. I stayed away from odors and foods that made me nauseated (I didn't have morning sickness but I had heartburn to beat the band) and when my daughter was born, she came out fine, very healthy, and the perfect weight. (She did have a lot of hair. Could have been that heartburn....)

Sixteen years later, I got pregnant again. We were better off so I ate better, but I couldn't handle the smell of coffee, so that was out, and I quit smoking for the duration of the pregnancy plus seven years. That pregnancy was dicier than the first because I was older, and (I admit it) fatter, but my second daughter came out okay, too, same as the first.

The thing is, Mother Nature has had a way of taking care of most infants-in-utero for the past umpteen billion years, so most mothers really don't have to to buy into the whole motherhood-as-a-competitive-sport thing.

The high-schoolers you pity may actually be quite happy. I don't think younger generations approach technology with the same sense of alienation and black-and-white thinking (e.g. you're either on your phone or present in the moment, but you can't be both). What would make an older person feel disconnected may be perfectly satisfying for a teenager. Perhaps that means the teenager is missing out on something, but not necessarily. The world changes, and adults have been bemoaning the demise of the next generation since classical times. The kids are usually all right.

Exactly. A scene I witnessed:

A young boy, around 4, and his father, who is texting.

"Daddy, are you listening?"

Distractedly: "Yes, I'm listening..."

"DADDY, are you LISTENING??"

Distractedly: "Yes, I'm listening..."

And so on.

I really, really, really, really hate people like that.

Dear Linda, OK

I was on the phone talking with a former student of mine, age 29, in NY. I was in AZ and am 64. We discussed people using the internet in some fashion to announce marriages,deaths,good news, bad news,minute likes and dislikes, and endless trivia. We were both most disturbed by seeing couples, friends and entire families enter restaurants of all types and immediately taking out their smartphones and either playing games or texting and only stopping when the meal arrived in order to eat, and then resuming the activities on their phones.

As a woman who spent her teens and twenties in the 60's era, I, of course, remember listening to radio, the first TV set at home, the ability to dial long distance after growing up using the operator, cars that had running boards, horse and buggies in Brooklyn, New York. I also revel in the fast moving technology and love much of it as well

My son has been a computer user since childhood, using a Commodore 64 when he was 3.

A really troubling story: My son was naturally personable and interacted well with other people. However, in order to avoid long lines at our bank, we began to use the numerous ATM's for transactions. One day, I wanted to show him how to deposit a check to his account in person. As we stood on the line, he turned to me, and in a frightened manner asked "what do I say to the person?" I knew then that I needed to be more aware, as his parent, that he be able to interact with real people in real space.

It is prom night here and I happened to be eating out at a restaurant that was full of young women in evening gowns. They were, most of them, taping away on their smart phones. I looked around at the other tables, where people weren't prom goers, and at nearly each table someone was tapping away on a phone while the other person he or she was with looked around uncomfortably like he or she was trying to act busy while the other person ignored them. Of course we are isolated. The most important person in our lives is never the person we are with and ignoring but the person we are yapping to or tapping away to on the phone. The worst I see are all the moms who yap away on the phones while pushing strollers. Nobody seems interested in the people they are with, whether it is their children, a friend, or a prom date.

Ridiculous!  In the 30s and 40s and 50s, I saw no fat kids in my schools (small ones to be sure), and few fat parents.  Obese parents teach, by example, their kids to be obese.  In my father's generation--1900-1978, obesity was very rare--as was asthma .  Genetic change can't account for the abrupt rise of obesity in the US (and Canada) in the 80's, 90s, and into the 21st century.

Or as Jim Hightower calls it "tinkle-down economics" where we're all a bunch of pee-ons. The working class has been waiting 30 years for the trickle to reach them. Can we admit yet that that theory doesn't work?

Trickle up (aka Keynseian) economics works. Put people to work, they'll have money to spend, they'll buy stuff, and everybody profits. CEOs get their bonusses, stockholders get their dividends, companies hire, and governments get their revenues.

"The bill’s proponents, led by Majority Leader Eric Cantor, say that lower taxes would lead to more hiring."

Right. This strategy worked so well when major banks were given huge bailouts during the financial crisis, even though their recklessness was a key factor in instigating the Great Recession. The idea was that the banks, given additional capital, would then lend it out and help encourage a recovery, but this did not happen. Supposedly lower taxes for business would encourage hiring though this likely will not happen to any significant degree, as the goal of many businesses is to generate as much profit as possible and hiring additional employees has some additional cost. As one business commentator noted recently, many corporations have "learned to do with fewer employees".

Republicans seem quite fond of the phrase "trickle down" economics.

Trickle. A slow, small, or irregular quantity that moves, proceeds, or occurs intermittently.
~ The American Heritage® Dictionary

I am American and my 3 children were born in France.  I lived in four different régions and raised them through both the French private and public school systems for over 17 years; 7 different cantines in all.  Firstly, each cantine at each school is different.  Secondly, unlike in the US, most French public schools are better funded than private schools.  If I had to guess, I would think the public school cantines are just as healthy if not healthier  than the private school ones and, yes, my children often ate endives, cauliflower and beets in cantines.  All of the cantines served a balanced, healthy meal and the children ate it.  There were very few unhealthy options - or they were considered a special treat.  One cantine served French fries only once a year (the day that the upcoming 6emes were visiting the school).  All the children looked forward to it and talked about it.  Also, a general comment about how French children can not be "picky" eaters.  Simply, if the child doesn't want to eat something the parents know that once they get hungry they'll eat; then they learn to like the food.  The author of this article is right, eating is a pleasure in France and It is a very important part of French life.  One more thought about an above comment, this has nothing to do with money.  French people with very little money still eat well.  There are many inexpensive, fast and healthy options for preparing food and the French know this.

I was also at my skinniest while living for a while in Edinburgh- despite the fact that I was working at a catering company, where many of our staff meals were things like chip butties. (For Americans, the equivalent of a french fry sandwich on a white roll).

Have to say, though, I've lived in/ visited Durham and elsewhere in Northern England fairly recently, and many people do seem to be overweight these days. (On par with the U.S.). I imagine there might have been a lot of changes in portion sizes, activity levels, etc., since you were growing up.
Probably too many chip butties

Oddly, when I lived in poverty in Northern England, me and my friends were really skinny. I'm not complaining, being skinny was actually fine. We ate only what was required to be less hungry, not trying to be "full." In the USA it appears to be always a goal, when eating, to achieve "fullness." Its not just the French eating well, Europeans collectively eat proper portions of food, healthy food not fast food, and don't swill down their food with super-sized, corn syrup fortified sugary drinks. Food for thought, American parents.

"But a kinder, gentler kind of authoritarianism — what the blogger James Poulos has dubbed “the pink police state,” which is officially tolerant while scrutinizing your every move — remains a live possibility.

Today, social media are hailed for empowering dissidents and undercutting tyrannies around the world. Yet it’s hard not to watch the Google video and agree with Forbes’s Kashmir Hill when she suggests that such a technology could ultimately “accelerate the arrival of the persistent and pervasive citizen surveillance state,” in which everything you see and do can be recorded, reported, subpoenaed ... you name it."

"Even the Catholic Church of the Middle Ages was tolerant by modern standards. Part of the reason for this was that in the past no government had the power to keep its citizens under constant surveillance. The invention of print, however, made it easier to manipulate public opinion, and the film and the radio carried the process further. With the development of television, and the technical advance which made it possible to receive and transmit simultaneously on the same instrument, private life came to an end."
~ From the novel 1984, Part 2, Chapter 9

The pink, tolerant state that you envision would surely be in a position to "help".

I wonder what criteria would be used.

Intense individualism and weak communal ties were scarcely the goals of either communist or fascist states. Both encouraged conformity and did not like privacy. Intense individualism and weak communal ties are the goals of anarchy and libertarians.

Citizen surveillance may not be here yet, but consumer surveillance is already at work. Invasion of privacy to find what things a person might be persuaded to buy is widespread. Such surveillance arises naturally in a free market because it gives a market advantage to those privy to its results. It can only be limited by government intervention in the normal workings of the market, which is anathema to conservatives.

When we lived in small towns the local merchants knew us personally, knew our likes and dislikes, and would make suggestions based on this knowledge. Now, thanks to computer data crunching, we are back in this situation and find it disturbing. Our accustomed anonymity of mall or strip mall is disappearing; on the internet, the web pages know what we have been looking at or buying and tailor their ads accordingly.

A pink, tolerant police state that keeps tabs on what you are doing without trying to stop or hinder you except when you were really out of line -- that is like the good sort of village that respects and cherishes its oddball characters rather than driving them out. Such a police state would allow intense individualism without demanding it.

Ann S,

Remember, the primary discussion here is PPA and alternative proposals--not Medicare.

Nevertheless, all programs suffer from the same defect of unnecessary complexity. There is no escaping the fact that if you want nearly universal health care, the wealthier segment of the population is going to have to subsidize the less wealthy. The only issue is how best this transfer of wealth is to be accomplished with the least negative effect on efficient pricing (see Bart's comment above). In this respect, wealth is relative, not absolute. Again, it makes no economic sense to take X dollars from the subsidizing segment of the population and to give that same segement Y dollars back with the other hand. Here, the difference between taxing and spending is truly blurred.

If nearly everyone over 65 in America is as "poor" as you suggest, where are the funds to come from to pay for their medical costs?

The over 65 cohort have a higher median income than do some other cohorts, particularly when one considers married couples (they have much more than double the median income of singles you cite). And, they typically have much greater wealth and fewer non-health related expenses. If we cut spending on the relatively wealthy, we can better afford spending on those who need help the most.

As for Medicare, it is already means tested. Premiums are higher for higher-income folks. Means testing will inevitably increase, but we are now doing this primarily be stealth.
If that's all there is, I respectfully submit that, unless the clue is alterred to indicate "erroneous usage" or "French", they've given us the wrong finger...
